      • AbstractBone

        public AbstractBone​(AbstractBone par,
                    SGVec_3d tipHeading,
                    SGVec_3d rollHeading,
                    java.lang.String inputTag,
                    double inputBoneHeight,
                    AbstractBone.frameType coordinateType)
             throws IKExceptions.NullParentForBoneException
        Parameters:
        par - the parent bone for this bone
        tipHeading - the orienational heading of this bone (global vs relative coords specified in coordinateType)
        rollHeading - axial rotation heading of the bone (it's z-axis)
        inputTag - some user specified name for the bone, if desired
        inputBoneHeight - bone length
        coordinateType -
        Throws:
        IKExceptions.NullParentForBoneException

      • AbstractBone

        public AbstractBone​(AbstractBone par,
                    double xAngle,
                    double yAngle,
                    double zAngle,
                    java.lang.String inputTag,
                    double inputBoneHeight)
             throws IKExceptions.NullParentForBoneException
        Parameters:
        par - the parent bone to which this bone is attached.
        xAngle - how much the bone should be pitched relative to its parent bone
        yAngle - how much the bone should be rolled relative to its parent bone
        zAngle - how much the bone should be yawed relative to its parent bone
        inputTag - some user specified name for the bone, if desired
        inputBoneHeight - bone length
        Throws:
        IKExceptions.NullParentForBoneException

      • AbstractBone

        public AbstractBone​(AbstractBone par,
                    SGVec_3d tipHeading,
                    SGVec_3d rollHeading,
                    java.lang.String inputTag,
                    AbstractBone.frameType coordinateType)
             throws IKExceptions.NullParentForBoneException
        Creates a new bone of specified length emerging from the parentBone. The new bone extends in the same exact direction as the parentBone. You can then manipulate its orientation using something like rotAboutFrameX(), rotAboutFrameY(), or rotAboutFrameZ(). You can also change its frame of rotation using setFrameOfRotation(Axes rotationFrame);
        Parameters:
        par - the parent bone to which this bone is attached.
        inputTag - some user specified name for the bone, if desired
        inputBoneHeight - bone length
        Throws:
        IKExceptions.NullParentForBoneException

      • snapToConstraints

        public void snapToConstraints()

      • IKUpdateNotification

        public void IKUpdateNotification()
        Called whenever this bone's orientation has changed due to an Inverse Kinematics computation. This function is called only once per IK solve, not per iteration. Meaning one call to Solve IK **SHOULD NOT** results in more than one call to each affected bone. However, the code that calls this function has not been thoroughly tested against edge cases, and you may wish to verify that it is working as intended. In particular, the concern is that a bone might under some circumstances be notified multiple times, but you can safely assume it will be called at least once.

      • setAxesToSnapped

        public void setAxesToSnapped​(AbstractAxes toSet,
                             AbstractAxes limitingAxes)
        same as snapToConstraints, but operates on user supplied axes meant to correspond to the bone's localAxes and majorRotationAxes you are unlikely to need to use this, and at the moment it presumes KusudamaExample constraints

      • getXZYAngle

        public double[] getXZYAngle()
                     throws IKExceptions.NullParentForBoneException
        Returns:
        an array where each element indicated how much this bone is rotated on the X,Y,Z (in that order) axes relative to its parent bone. If the bone has no parent, this method throws an exception.
        Throws:
        IKExceptions.NullParentForBoneException

      • getRotation

        public Rot getRotation()
        Returns:
        An Apache Commons Rotation object representing the rotation of this bone relative to its reference frame. The Rotation object is more versatile and robust than an array of angles. And allows you to treat rotation in a wide variety of conventions.

      • getRotationFromPrevious

        public Rot getRotationFromPrevious()
        Returns:
        An Apache Commons Rotation object representing the rotation which transforms this BoneExample from its previous orientation to its current orientation.

      • getPreviousOrientation

        public AbstractAxes getPreviousOrientation()
        Returns:

        Parameters:

      • setFrameofRotation

        public void setFrameofRotation​(AbstractAxes rotationFrameCoordinates)
        Parameters:
        rotationFrameCoordinates - the Axes around which rotAboutFrameX, rotAboutFrameY, and rotAboutFrameZ will rotate, and against which getXZYAngle() will be computed. The input is expected to be in RELATIVE coordinates. so specifying these axes as having an
        x component heading of (1,0,0) and
        y component heading of (0,1,0) and
        z component heading of (0,0,1)

        is equivalent to specifying the frameOfRotation of this bone as being perfectly aligned with the localAxes of its parent bone.

        The physical intuition of this is maybe something like "at what angle did I place the servos on this joint"

        It doesn't necessarily determine where the bone can rotate, but it does determine *how* the bone would rotate to get there.

        This is also used to set constraints. For example, euler constraints are computed against these axes and the limitCones and axial twist limits of KusudamaExample are specified relative to these Axes.

        Changing these axes is essentially the equivalent of rotating the joint on which this bone rests, while keeping the bone in globally in place.

        You don't need to change this unless you start wishing you could change this.

      • getMajorRotationAxes

        public AbstractAxes getMajorRotationAxes()

      • disablePin

        public void disablePin()
        Disables the pin for this bone so that it no longer interests the IK Solver. However, all information abut the pin is maintained, so the pin can be turned on again with enablePin().

      • removePin

        public void removePin()
        Entirely removes the pin from this bone. Any child pins attached to it are reparented to this pin's parent.

      • createAndReturnPinAtOrigin

      • getStiffness

        public double getStiffness()
        The stiffness of a bone determines how much the IK solver should prefer to avoid rotating it if it can. A value of 0 means the solver will rotate this bone as much as the overall dampening parameter will allow it to per iteration. A value of 0.5 means the solver will rotate it half as much as the dampening parameter will allow, and a value of 1 effectively means the solver is not allowed to rotate this bone at all.
        Returns:
        a value between 1 and 0.

      • setStiffness

        public void setStiffness​(double stiffness)
